docs.snippet: Guy Rodgers, a four-time National Basketball Association All-Star, a two-time all-American at Temple University and one of the most talented guards and playmakers of his era, died Monday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 65.    Rodgers was atte...
docs.lead_paragraph: Guy Rodgers, a four-time National Basketball Association All-Star, a two-time all-American at Temple University and one of the most talented guards and playmakers of his era, died Monday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 65. Rodgers was attending a movie when he apparently suffered a heart attack, said Sonny Hill, a family friend.
docs.abstract: Guy Rodgers, former basketball star, dies at age 65; photo (M)

headline.main: Guy Rodgers, an N.B.A. All-Star, Dies at 65

docs.snippet: Pope John Paul II elevated 44 men today to the rank of cardinal, the largest number in history, in a ceremony that mingled ancient pageantry with the more immediate aim of molding the institution that will someday choose his successor.    After th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Pope John Paul II elevated 44 men today to the rank of cardinal, the largest number in history, in a ceremony that mingled ancient pageantry with the more immediate aim of molding the institution that will someday choose his successor. After the cardinals, dressed in their new scarlet cassocks but still bareheaded, recited an oath of fidelity to the pope and his successors, John Paul received them one by one at his golden throne in front of St. Peter's basilica, handing them the biretta, the red silk hat that symbolized their new rank.
docs.abstract: Pope John Paul II elevates 44 men to rank of cardinal, largest number ever, rite, Rome; has now named 166 cardinals, more than any other pope, and all but 10 of 135 cardinals eligible to vote for next pope; choses prelates who espouse his traditionalist views and bring greater geographical and ethnic diversity to assembly that will choose his successor; three Americans elevated are Cardinals Edward M Egan, Theodore E McCarrick and Avery Dulles; photos (M)

headline.main: Shaping a Legacy, Pope Installs 44 Cardinals

docs.snippet: Bogus good taste is not punished enough. It was a great pleasure last week to see the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences punish the infuriatingly bogus and tasteful ''House of Mirth'' by denying it any Oscar nominations. And this despite ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Bogus good taste is not punished enough. It was a great pleasure last week to see the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences punish the infuriatingly bogus and tasteful ''House of Mirth'' by denying it any Oscar nominations. And this despite that aura of high aesthetic integrity that so often impresses -- or at least guilt-trips -- Hollywood. ''The House of Mirth'' is an art house success. But film art houses do business the same way art auction houses do: they have to sell what they can get and make it look as desirable as they can. We all complain about the cynicism of mass market movies: dumb stories, predictable acting, scripts and direction by the numbers. (Market survey numbers that is, based on the age, gender, race, ethnicity and, that trusty textbook euphemism, the socioeconomic background of audience members.) We're right to complain, but we may be getting a little too desperate for our own good.
docs.abstract: Margo Jefferson scores Terence Davies' screen version of Edith Wharton's House of Mirth, finding it ostentatiously highbrow, infuriatingly bogus; photos (L)

headline.main: The Film of Taste: Just Add Soft Lighting and Close-Ups

docs.snippet: Stanley Kramer, the producer and director of socially groundbreaking films like ''The Defiant Ones'' and ''Judgment at Nuremberg'' and one of Hollywood's most respected filmmakers in the late 1950's and early 60's, died on Monday in Woodland Hills...
docs.lead_paragraph: Stanley Kramer, the producer and director of socially groundbreaking films like ''The Defiant Ones'' and ''Judgment at Nuremberg'' and one of Hollywood's most respected filmmakers in the late 1950's and early 60's, died on Monday in Woodland Hills, a section of Los Angeles. He was 87. Mr. Kramer never liked being described as a ''message filmmaker,'' but that was the tag that stuck to him throughout his long career. He retained this reputation even in the 60's and 70's, when many of his films faltered at the box office and changing tastes persuaded a new generation of critics, weaned on the French new wave and the auteur theory, to view his work as sentimental and simplistic.
docs.abstract: Stanley Kramer, producer and director of socially groundbreaking films like Judgment at Nuremberg and Guess Who's Coming for Dinner, dies at age 87; Kramer, one of Hollywood's most respected filmmakers in late 1950's and early 1960's, was born in New York's Hell's Kitchen, and began career eager to shake up status quo with string of socially conscious movies that raised issues like racial inequality; his acclaimed western High Noon was actually thinly veiled attack on McCarthy purges, while The Wild One with Marlon Brando, first biker film, dealt with juvenile delinquency; career highlights; photos (M)

headline.main: Stanley Kramer, Filmmaker With Social Bent, Dies at 87

docs.snippet: Howard W. Koch, a veteran producer and director whose credits include ''The Manchurian Candidate'' and the television series ''Maverick,'' died on Friday. He was 84.    Mr. Koch, a former president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Science...
docs.lead_paragraph: Howard W. Koch, a veteran producer and director whose credits include ''The Manchurian Candidate'' and the television series ''Maverick,'' died on Friday. He was 84. Mr. Koch, a former president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and head of production at Paramount Pictures from 1964 to 1966, was still a producer at Paramount at the time of his death, having kept the same office and personal assistant for 35 years.
docs.abstract: Howard W Koch, film and television producer and director, dies at age 84 (M)

docs.snippet: The Writers Guild of America has been sequestered for four weeks in talks with the major studios and television networks, allowing a gradual, creeping sense of optimism to build in Hollywood that perhaps, just perhaps, a settlement may yet be reac...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Writers Guild of America has been sequestered for four weeks in talks with the major studios and television networks, allowing a gradual, creeping sense of optimism to build in Hollywood that perhaps, just perhaps, a settlement may yet be reached to forestall long-dreaded dual strikes this summer by the industry's writers and actors. Initially, John Wells, the guild's president, said that the writers would only negotiate for two weeks, unless significant progress was being made. Without such progress, he said, talks would be halted until closer to the expiration of the contract with producers on May 1.
docs.abstract: Four weeks of talks between Writers Guild of America and major film studios and television networks foster hope that agreement may be reached to forestall strikes this summer by both writers and actors represented by Screen (M)

headline.main: Writers Strike May Not Be Inevitable

docs.snippet: HOW I CAME INTO MY INHERITANCE  And Other True Stories  By Dorothy Gallagher  187 pages. Random House. $22.95.    BALD IN THE LAND OF BIG HAIR  A True Story  By Joni Rodgers  253 pages. HarperCollins. $24.       Cancer and communism may not be lau...
docs.lead_paragraph: HOW I CAME INTO MY INHERITANCE And Other True Stories By Dorothy Gallagher 187 pages. Random House. $22.95. BALD IN THE LAND OF BIG HAIR A True Story By Joni Rodgers 253 pages. HarperCollins. $24. Cancer and communism may not be laughing matters, but they're funnier than you'd think in two new memoirs by unusually candid and gutsy women. Joni Rodgers, who was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and writes frankly about her experiences in ''Bald in the Land of Big Hair,'' tries to find a joke at every possible turn, as in: ''Why didn't the home health nurse cross the road? Because the chicken's H.M.O. wouldn't approve it!''
docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews Bald in the Land of Big Hair: A True Story by Joni Rodgers; reviews How I Came Into My Inheritance: And Other True Stories by Dorothy Gallagher; photos (M)

headline.main: Facing Chemo or Pinkos, and Still Smilin'

docs.snippet: AT first blush, the two main contenders for this year's Oscar for best picture, ''Gladiator,'' which received 12 nominations last week, and ''Traffic,'' which received five, could hardly be less similar. The first is a costume drama, the second co...
docs.lead_paragraph: AT first blush, the two main contenders for this year's Oscar for best picture, ''Gladiator,'' which received 12 nominations last week, and ''Traffic,'' which received five, could hardly be less similar. The first is a costume drama, the second contemporary. The first is stately, the second kinetic, almost documentary in style; the first narratively conventional, the second kaleidoscopic. Nor could the stories these films tell seem more different. The ostensible subject of ''Traffic'' is drug trafficking, which the film examines from various perspectives in interlocking episodes -- from the newly appointed American drug czar (Michael Douglas) and his preppy 16-year-old daughter (Erika Christensen), herself caught in drug hell, to a beautiful and pregnant San Diego socialite (Catherine Zeta-Jones), whose posh lifestyle is suddenly threatened when her husband is arrested for drug dealing.
docs.abstract: Neal Gabler comments on movies Gladiator and Traffic, two main contenders for this year's Oscar for best picture, observing that both films, while seemingly different on the surface, both seem to have tapped same wellsprings of discontent and anxiety in modern America, and deal with same subject: a society in throes of amusing itself to death and cost of doing so; photo (M)

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; In Oscar Race, Family Prevails

docs.snippet: A RAVISHING teenage model in the Marc Jacobs show was driving André Leon Talley batty. It wasn't the clothes: goodness no, he adored the clothes. It was her toes. As she traversed the runway, hips rocking, eyes as frozen as a doll's, the toes, on...
docs.lead_paragraph: A RAVISHING teenage model in the Marc Jacobs show was driving André Leon Talley batty. It wasn't the clothes: goodness no, he adored the clothes. It was her toes. As she traversed the runway, hips rocking, eyes as frozen as a doll's, the toes, one gathered, were pointing absolutely in the wrong direction. Or so Mr. Talley, the larger-than-life editor at large of Vogue, informed viewers last week during the wall-to-wall coverage of Fashion Week on the Metro Channel program ''Full Frontal Fashion.''
docs.abstract: Comment on television coverage of New York Fashion Week by local cable stations (S)
